user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_Stub_CallOnce:
```c
void UT_Stub_CallOnce(void (*Func)(void))
{
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr;
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *OnceEnt;
    UT_EntryKey_t        FuncKey;
    int32                i;

    if (Func == NULL)
    {
        return;
    }

    FuncKey = (UT_EntryKey_t)Func;
    OnceEnt = NULL;
    StubPtr = UT_StubTable;
    for (i = 0; i < UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS; ++i)
    {
        if (StubPtr->EntryType == UT_ENTRYTYPE_UNUSED && OnceEnt == NULL)
        {
            OnceEnt = StubPtr;
        }
        else if (StubPtr->EntryType == UT_ENTRYTYPE_CALL_ONCE && StubPtr->FuncKey == FuncKey)
        {
            OnceEnt = StubPtr;
            break;
        }
        ++StubPtr;
    }

    if (OnceEnt == NULL)
    {
        /* should never happen -- UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS needs increase if it does */
        UtAssert_Abort("Cannot do CallOnce - UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS too low?");
    }
    else if (OnceEnt->EntryType == UT_ENTRYTYPE_UNUSED)
    {
        OnceEnt->EntryType = UT_ENTRYTYPE_CALL_ONCE;
        OnceEnt->FuncKey   = FuncKey;

        Func();
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UT_Stub_CallOnce:
typedef struct
{
    UT_EntryType_t EntryType;
    uint32         ModeFlags;
    UT_EntryKey_t  FuncKey;
    UT_EntryData_t Data;
} UT_StubTableEntry_t
...
static UT_StubTableEntry_t UT_StubTable[UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS] = {{0}}
...
typedef cpuaddr UT_EntryKey_t
...
void UtAssert_Abort(const char *Message)
{
    UT_BSP_DoText(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_ABORT, Message);
}
...
#define UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS 200
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
Reasoning about other pointer usages in the function and related definitions that do not need investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13:

- UT_StubTableEntry_t *OnceEnt; and subsequent writes OnceEnt->EntryType = ...; OnceEnt->FuncKey = ...; — OnceEnt is used to modify the pointed-to table entry. Because the code intentionally writes to the pointee, making the pointed-to type const would be incorrect, so these occurrences are not candidates for Rule 8.13.

- The global UT_StubTable array is written to by this code (entries are initialized/modified), so it cannot be made const; therefore the table itself and pointers used to modify it are not candidates.

- The function parameter void (*Func)(void) refers to a function object. C does not support const-qualified function types in the sense required by Rule 8.13 (qualifying the function type with const is not meaningful), so that parameter is not a valid target for this rule.

- UtAssert_Abort takes a const char * and string literals are already const-like; this usage complies with the rule.

- The cast FuncKey = (UT_EntryKey_t)Func converts a function pointer to an integer type; this is not about pointer-to-const qualification and thus outside the scope of Rule 8.13.

The selected fragments are the places where a pointer to the table is declared/used only for reading/traversal (StubPtr) and then assigned to OnceEnt; StubPtr appears to only read the table entries, so per Rule 8.13 it could be considered to point to a const-qualified type and therefore warrants investigation. No other pointer usages in the function present the same opportunity for adding a const qualification to the pointed-to type.
